1.title: Simulation: Supporting Jamie (Student with Dyslexia) in a Fraction Word Problem

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Hi Jamie! I noticed your answer used 3 smoothies, but the question says 4. Let’s take another look together.

conversation.speaker: Jamie
conversation.text: Oh… I thought it said 3 smoothies. I must have read it wrong.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: That’s okay! Word problems can be tricky, especially when numbers are mixed in with a lot of text. One thing that helps is underlining key information. Let’s try that now.

conversation.speaker: Jamie
conversation.text: Okay. I see it now—it says 4 smoothies, not 3.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Great! Now, each smoothie needs 2/3 cup of milk. What should we do if we’re making 4 of them?

conversation.speaker: Jamie
conversation.text: Multiply 4 by 2/3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Exactly! Let's solve that together. What do we get when we multiply 4 times 2?

conversation.speaker: Jamie
conversation.text: That’s 8. So it’s 8 over 3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: You got it! 8/3 is the answer in improper fraction form. Can we turn that into a mixed number?

conversation.speaker: Jamie
conversation.text: 3 goes into 8 two times with 2 left over, so it’s 2 and 2/3 cups!

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Well done, Jamie! Underlining numbers really helped. Keep using that trick when reading word problems!

1.problem: Each smoothie needs 2/3 cup of milk. Sam wants to make 4 smoothies. How much milk does he need in total?

2.title: Simulation: Supporting Riley (Student with Dysgraphia) in a Fraction Problem

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Hi Riley! I see you’ve written your work here—let’s take a look together.

conversation.speaker: Riley
conversation.text: Sorry, it’s really messy… I kept losing track of the numbers.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: No worries at all. That’s totally okay. Let’s go through it step by step. The question says each smoothie needs 2/3 cup of milk and you’re making 4 smoothies. What do you think we need to do?

conversation.speaker: Riley
conversation.text: Um… I think I started adding 2/3 four times, but I got confused writing the fractions. They kept getting jumbled.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: That makes sense. Writing fractions neatly can be tricky, especially if spacing is tight or numbers shift around. Want to try using colored blocks or typing it out instead?

conversation.speaker: Riley
conversation.text: Yeah, maybe typing would help. My hand gets tired fast too.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Great idea. Now, let’s talk it out. If we do 4 × 2/3, what’s 4 times 2?

conversation.speaker: Riley
conversation.text: That’s 8. So it’s 8 over 3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Exactly! 8/3. Can you say what that is as a mixed number?

conversation.speaker: Riley
conversation.text: 3 goes into 8 twice, with 2 left. So it’s 2 and 2/3 cups.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Perfect! You understood the problem really well. Let’s use assistive tools next time so your writing doesn’t get in the way of showing what you know.

3.title: Simulation: Supporting Ken (Student with Dyscalculia) in a Fraction Problem

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Hey Ken! Let’s look at the smoothie problem together. I see you wrote down 5 cups of milk. Can you walk me through your thinking?

conversation.speaker: Ken
conversation.text: Yeah… I saw 2 and 3 in the fraction, so I just added them to get 5. Then I thought that’s how much milk I need.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Thanks for explaining. I really like that you're trying to work with the numbers! That fraction, 2/3, is actually one amount — two-thirds of a cup. Not 2 and 3 separately.

conversation.speaker: Ken
conversation.text: Oh… I thought it meant both 2 and 3 separately. Fractions are confusing.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: They can be, but we’ll get through it together. Imagine 4 smoothies, each needing 2/3 cup. That means we’re repeating 2/3 four times. That’s multiplication.

conversation.speaker: Ken
conversation.text: So… instead of adding 2 and 3, I should do 4 times 2/3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Exactly! Let’s multiply it: 4 times 2 is 8, and the denominator stays 3. That gives us 8/3.

conversation.speaker: Ken
conversation.text: Okay, 8/3. That’s more than 2… so it’s 2 and… 2/3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Perfect! 2 and 2/3 cups of milk. And next time you see a fraction, remember — it’s one number showing part of a whole, not two pieces to be added.

conversation.speaker: Ken
conversation.text: Thanks! That actually makes more sense now. I’ll try to remember that.

4.title: Simulation: Supporting Jordan (Student with ADHD) in a Fraction Problem

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Hey Jordan! I noticed your answer says 3 cups. Want to walk me through how you got that?

conversation.speaker: Jordan
conversation.text: Um… I think I was adding 2/3, then I got distracted and forgot if I had 3 or 4 smoothies. So I just guessed.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Thanks for being honest! That’s totally okay. Let’s take it one small step at a time. The problem says: 4 smoothies, and each needs 2/3 cup of milk. What’s the first thing we can do?

conversation.speaker: Jordan
conversation.text: We… repeat 2/3 four times?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Yes! And repeating the same number is the same as multiplying. So what’s 4 times 2?

conversation.speaker: Jordan
conversation.text: That’s 8. So the answer is 8 over 3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Exactly! Now let’s finish strong—how many times does 3 go into 8?

conversation.speaker: Jordan
conversation.text: Twice, with 2 left over. So it’s 2 and 2/3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Nailed it! You stayed focused and worked through each step. Try using a checklist or even a finger tap for each part next time—that can help keep track.

conversation.speaker: Jordan
conversation.text: Yeah, that helped. When I go step-by-step, I don’t get as overwhelmed.

5.title: Simulation: Supporting Maya (Student with Auditory Processing Disorder) in a Fraction Problem

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Hi Maya! Let's go over this problem together. The question is: Each smoothie needs 2/3 cup of milk. If Sam wants to make 4 smoothies, how much milk will he need in total?

conversation.speaker: Maya
conversation.text: ...Wait—did you say 2 cups for 3 smoothies?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Ah, not quite. Let me slow it down and repeat it clearly: Each smoothie needs two-thirds of a cup of milk. Sam wants to make four smoothies. How much milk does he need?

conversation.speaker: Maya
conversation.text: Okay, two-thirds for each… and there are four… smoothies?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Yes, perfect! Now, we’re using the same amount—two-thirds—four times. What operation do you think that is?

conversation.speaker: Maya
conversation.text: Is it multiplication? Like 4 × 2/3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Exactly! And 4 times 2 is?

conversation.speaker: Maya
conversation.text: 8. So that’s 8/3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Right again. Can you turn 8/3 into a mixed number?

conversation.speaker: Maya
conversation.text: 3 goes into 8 two times, with 2 left. So, 2 and 2/3.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Great work, Maya! And if anything I say is ever unclear, it’s always okay to ask me to slow down or repeat it. You're doing an amazing job!

6.title: Simulation: Supporting Eli (Student with Nonverbal Learning Disorder) in a Fraction Problem

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Hey Eli! I saw your answer said 4/2 cups of milk. Want to share how you got that?

conversation.speaker: Eli
conversation.text: I tried putting the 4 and 2 together… but I wasn’t sure where the numbers go in the fraction. It’s hard to picture it.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Thanks for telling me that. Fractions can be hard to visualize, especially when they involve multiple steps. Want to try breaking it down using words instead of pictures?

conversation.speaker: Eli
conversation.text: Yeah, I do better with words.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Alright, the question says: Each smoothie needs 2/3 cup of milk. If you're making 4 smoothies, you’ll need 2/3 cup four times. That means we multiply 4 × 2/3. What’s 4 times 2?

conversation.speaker: Eli
conversation.text: That’s 8. So we put that over 3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Exactly—8/3. Now, if we want to turn 8/3 into a regular number, how many times does 3 go into 8?

conversation.speaker: Eli
conversation.text: Twice, with 2 leftover. So… 2 and 2/3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Yes! That’s the total milk you’d need. You really nailed it when we focused on the words and steps instead of the shapes or diagrams.

conversation.speaker: Eli
conversation.text: Yeah, it helps when I don’t have to imagine stuff like that. I understand better when we just talk through it.

7.title: Simulation: Supporting Nora (Student with Language Processing Disorder) in a Fraction Problem

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Hey Nora! Let’s read this problem together: Each smoothie needs 2/3 cup of milk. If Sam wants to make 4 smoothies, how much milk does he need?

conversation.speaker: Nora
conversation.text: ...Wait. What do you mean by 'each' smoothie? I’m not sure what that means.

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Great question. ‘Each’ means every one. So, if Sam makes one smoothie, he needs 2/3 cup of milk. If he makes four, we need to figure out how much milk he needs total.

conversation.speaker: Nora
conversation.text: Oh… okay. So, we have 2/3 four times?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Exactly. That’s multiplication. When we have the same amount repeated, like 2/3 four times, we can multiply 4 × 2/3.

conversation.speaker: Nora
conversation.text: So, 4 times 2 is 8… then I keep the 3 on the bottom?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Yes! That gives us 8/3. Now we’ll change that into a mixed number. How many times does 3 go into 8?

conversation.speaker: Nora
conversation.text: Two times, and there’s 2 left. So… 2 and 2/3?

conversation.speaker: Tutor
conversation.text: Perfect! If any part of a question is confusing, it’s always okay to ask. Understanding what the question says is just as important as doing the math!

conversation.speaker: Nora
conversation.text: Thanks. I feel better when you explain the words step by step like that.
